docs.title: Sample Prompt
docs.text:
Create a glossary of terms for a course in Internet of Things. 
Return the glossary in markdown format with term names in header four format "####"
For each term, provide a precise, concise definition and then list related concepts in a unnumbered list.
 Make sure the list is returned in alphabetical format.
Include terms such as 4G, Backhaul, Cloud, DSP, I2C, SPI, WiFi, Bluetooth, MicroPython, TinyML, IRQ, data logging

docs.title: 4G
docs.text:
Fourth-generation cellular network technology, providing faster data transmission speeds compared to 3G networks.

  • Related to LTE, mobile internet, high-speed data transmission

docs.title: Backhaul
docs.text:
The intermediate links between the core network and small subnetworks at the edge of the entire network.

  • Related to network infrastructure, data transport, broadband

docs.title: Bluetooth
docs.text:
A wireless technology standard for exchanging data over short distances using short-wavelength UHF radio waves.

  • Related to wireless communication, IoT devices, personal area networks

docs.title: Cloud
docs.text:
Centralized data storage and processing services accessed over the internet.

  • Related to data centers, cloud computing, remote processing

docs.title: Data Logging
docs.text:
The process of collecting and storing data over time, often from sensors or instruments.

  • Related to data analysis, monitoring, IoT sensors

docs.title: DSP (Digital Signal Processing)
docs.text:
The use of digital processing (like computers or specialized DSP chips) to analyze, modify, or synthesize signals such as sound, images, and sensor data.

  • Related to signal analysis, data compression, noise reduction

docs.title: I2C (Inter-Integrated Circuit)
docs.text:
A multi-master, multi-slave, packet-switched, single-ended, serial computer bus widely used for attaching lower-speed peripheral ICs to processors and microcontrollers.

  • Related to communication protocol, microcontrollers, peripheral devices

docs.title: IRQ (Interrupt Request)
docs.text:
A hardware signal sent to the processor that temporarily stops a running program and allows a special program, an interrupt handler, to run instead.

  • Related to computer hardware, interrupts, microprocessors

docs.title: MicroPython
docs.text:
A lean and efficient implementation of the Python 3 programming language, designed to run on microcontrollers and in constrained environments.

  • Related to embedded systems, Python programming, IoT development

docs.title: SPI (Serial Peripheral Interface)
docs.text:
A synchronous serial communication interface specification used for short-distance communication, primarily in embedded systems.

  • Related to data transfer, microcontrollers, communication protocol

docs.title: TinyML
docs.text:
Refers to machine learning technologies capable of performing on-device analytics at extremely low power, suitable for tiny devices.

  • Related to artificial intelligence, low-power devices, edge computing

docs.title: WiFi
docs.text:
A family of wireless network protocols, based on the IEEE 802.11 family of standards, used for local area networking of devices and internet access.

  • Related to wireless networking, internet connectivity, routers

docs.title: Ubiquitous Computing
docs.text: The potential of the total, widespread adoption of connected devices and their benefits. Also known as pervasive computing, it can be described as the saturation of devices ingrained in work, life, and logistics.

docs.title: Internet of Things in Healthcare
docs.text: An outline of a 14-week Course Outline: Internet of Things (IoT) in Healthcare Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota

docs.title: Audience
docs.text:
• EECS students with a background in Python programming.
  • Possible overlap of students in the medical school.

docs.title: Week 1: Introduction to IoT
docs.text:
• Overview of IoT: Definition, history, and evolution
  • IoT architecture and components
  • Introduction to IoT in the context of Minnesota's medical device industry

docs.title: Week 2: IoT Technologies and Protocols
docs.text:
• Sensors and actuators in IoT
  • Communication protocols and networking in IoT
  • IoT standards and ecosystems

docs.title: Week 3: IoT Platforms and Tools
docs.text:
• Overview of popular IoT platforms
    • Raspberry Pi Pico W
    • ESP32
    • Arduino
  • Hands-on session with an IoT platform
    • Pico W Lab
  • Case studies of IoT platforms in medical devices
    • Medical sensor development
    • FDA approval process

docs.title: Week 4: IoT Data and Analytics
docs.text:
• Understanding data flow in IoT systems
  • Basics of data analytics and its importance in IoT
  • IoT data analytics in healthcare applications

docs.title: Week 5: IoT Security and Privacy
docs.text:
• Challenges in IoT security and privacy
  • Security protocols and best practices
  • Privacy concerns in healthcare IoT
  • Case study: home health monitoring

docs.title: Week 6: IoT in Healthcare
docs.text:
• Specific use cases of IoT in healthcare
  • Role of IoT in patient monitoring and diagnostics
  • IoT in hospital and clinical management

docs.title: Week 7: Wireless Technologies in IoT
docs.text:
• Introduction to wireless technologies in IoT
  • Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and LoRaWAN in healthcare IoT
  • Challenges and solutions in wireless IoT technologies

docs.title: Week 8: Mid-Term Project
docs.text: • Students work on a mid-term project focusing on designing an IoT solution for a healthcare problem

docs.title: Week 9: IoT and Big Data
docs.text:
• Intersection of IoT and data analysis
  • Analytics for healthcare IoT
  • Case studies of analysis of medical sensors

docs.title: Week 10: IoT Device Design and Development
docs.text:
• Basics of IoT device design
  • Prototyping IoT devices for healthcare applications
  • Regulatory considerations for medical IoT devices

docs.title: Week 11: IoT Integration and Implementation
docs.text:
• Integrating IoT devices with existing systems
  • Challenges in deploying IoT solutions in healthcare settings
  • Case study: IoT integration in a medical device company

docs.title: Week 12: IoT in Remote Healthcare
docs.text:
• IoT for telemedicine and remote patient monitoring
  • Wearable technologies in healthcare
  • IoT for emergency response and mobile health

docs.title: Week 13: Future Trends in IoT and Healthcare
docs.text:
• Emerging trends in IoT
  • The future of IoT in the medical device industry
  • Discussions on upcoming technologies and their potential impact

docs.title: Week 14: Final Project Presentations and Course Wrap-Up
docs.text:
• Students present their final projects
  • Review of key learnings and future directions in IoT
  • Evaluation and feedback session

docs.title: Audience
docs.text: College students with a background in Python.

docs.title: Materials
docs.text:
Each student will be provided with:

  1. A Raspberry Pi Pico "W"
  2. A USB cable
  3. A 1/2 size breadboard
  4. A 128x64 OLED display
  5. A Time-of-flight sensor

  6. Various wires

  7. Each student must provide a laptop with a USB port.

  8. Students must run the Thonny Python IDE or similar.
  9. Each student must have an account on GitHub.
  10. Knowledge of Markdown formats is helpful but not required

We will also provide examples of GPT-4 prompts that can be used to create, extend and debug your IoT code. A generative AI account is encouraged but not required.

docs.title: Week 1: Introduction to IoT and Raspberry Pi Pico "W"
docs.text:
• Overview of IoT concepts and applications
  • Case study: home health monitoring
  • Introduction to Raspberry Pi Pico "W": Specifications, capabilities
  • Setting up the Raspberry Pi Pico "W" environment
  • Basic programming with MicroPython
  • Hands-on Project: WiFi Clock

docs.title: Week 2: MicroPython and the Pico Deep Dive
docs.text:
• Detailed exploration of MicroPython
  • Differences between MicroPython and Python
  • MicroPython vs. C
  • Pico vs. the ESP-32
  • Using multiple cores
  • Basic control structures in MicroPython
  • Interfacing with the Raspberry Pi Pico "W" hardware
  • Tips on using generative AI to write, extend and debug
  • Hands-On Project: WiFi Weather Station

docs.title: Week 3: Sensors and Data Acquisition
docs.text:
• Overview of sensors used in IoT (temperature, motion, light, etc.)
  • Interfacing sensors with Raspberry Pi Pico "W"
  • The I2C Bus and sensors
  • The SPI Bus and displays
  • Reading and interpreting Time-of-Flight sensor data from an I2C
  • Hands-on project: Reporting distance

docs.title: Week 4: Networking and IoT Protocols
docs.text:
• Introduction to IoT communication protocols
  • Connecting Raspberry Pi Pico "W" to a network via WiFI
  • Sending and receiving data over the network
  • Basics of network security in IoT
  • The MQTT protocol for managing events
  • The Matter Smart Home Standard
  • Hands-on project: Web server

docs.title: Week 5: Edge Computing Concepts
docs.text:
• Understanding edge computing in the context of IoT
  • Benefits and challenges of edge computing
  • Implementing basic edge computing tasks with Raspberry Pi Pico "W"
  • Case studies of edge computing in IoT
  • TinyML
  • Hands-on project: Distance data logger

docs.title: Week 6: Cloud Computing and IoT
docs.text:
• Introduction to cloud-computing in IoT
  • Cloud platforms for IoT (AWS IoT, Azure IoT, etc.)
  • Sending data from Raspberry Pi Pico "W" to the cloud
  • Analyzing sensor data in the cloud

docs.title: Week 7: Data Analysis at the Edge vs. Cloud
docs.text:
• Tradeoffs between edge and cloud data processing
  • Efficiency, latency, and privacy considerations
  • Architecture tradeoff analysis
  • Real-world scenarios comparing edge and cloud analytics
  • Group discussion and case study analysis

docs.title: Week 8: Building an IoT Project (Part 1)
docs.text:
• Planning and designing a comprehensive IoT project
  • Selecting appropriate sensors and communication protocols
  • Purchasing parts: Sparkfun, Adafruit, and EBay
  • Developing the edge component of the project

docs.title: Week 9: Building an IoT Project (Part 2)
docs.text:
• Developing the cloud component of the project
  • Integrating edge and cloud components
  • Data analysis and interpretation
  • Troubleshooting and optimizing the IoT system

docs.title: Week 10: Project Presentations and Course Wrap-up
docs.text:
• Presentation of IoT projects by students
  • Feedback sessions and group discussions
  • Review of key concepts from the course
  • Future trends and opportunities in IoT
